>So said Jonathan Oddy on 2003-06-20 --------------------
<snip />
>Obviously I can (and have) refactored Action.execute and this has resulted
>in a number of protected and private methods. But unit testing seems be
>aimed at public interface testing, which my newly refactored methods do not
>come under this description.

I have done the following and been happy with it. Add a method (or even a class) that contains the raw business logic that your Action performs

* This method accepts as parameters any object that it might collaborate with.

* This method builds up ActionMessages (of all kinds) into a collection.

* This method accepts a Map parameter that represents the objects it wants to place on the Struts response

I test-drive this code. The code in my Action is almost foolproof:

* Create an ActionMessages and/or ActionErrors object.
* Dump the "response objects" into the request as attributes.
* Perform any required JNDI lookups to find the collaborating objects

Over time, I can extract these responsibilities into a template method and build a mini-framework for integrating my raw business logic.

I don't know whether this is what you're doing, or close to it, but I have used it with success.

I'm sorry if this is terse: I'll need to write it out in full for the book and don't have the energy to write it out in full now. :)

Feel free to ask specific questions on this, though. We can work through the code.
